Editorial changes were made throughout this section to add and to update or correct citations.

IPU 21U1025 issued 08/10/2021 IRM 5.9.11.1.7(8) - Updates TBOR content based on guidance from the Division Counsel/Associate Chief Counsel (National Taxpayer Advocate Program) and Branch 3 of the Associate Chief Counsel (Procedure and Administration).
IPU 21U1025 issued 08-10-2021 IRM 5.9.11.5(2) - Updates ﬁrst sentence to replace “unless” with “until” the taxpayer subsequently provides clear and concise notiﬁcation of a change of address.
IPU 21U1025 issued 08-10-2021 Editorial changes were made throughout this section to add clarity and to update or correct citations.
EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS

This material supersedes IRM 5.9.11 dated September 17, 2020. This revision incorporates IPU 21U0071 issued January 8, 2021, National Change of Address (NCOA) Database and IPU 21U1025 issued August 10,
Field Insolvency Groups and the Centralized Insolvency Operation.
Kareem Williams, Director Collection Policy, Small Self Employed
Table of Contents
Mail Processing
) Purpose. This section provides guidance for Specialty Collection - (SCI) employees related to mail processing. Scope and (
) Audience. This IRM section is used primarily by Specialty Collection - vency caseworkers in Field Insolvency (FI) and at the Centralized Operation (CIO). (
) Policy Owner. Director, Collection Policy, Small Business/Self Employed SE), (
) Program Owner. Collection Policy, SB/SE, Insolvency is the program (
) Primary Stakeholders. The primary stakeholders are Specialty Collection - Insolvency (SCI) and Small Business/Self Employed (SB/SE) Collection. (
) Program Goals.

The goal is to provide the fundamental knowledge and cedural guidance to facilitate the effective mail process of Insolvency cases and to promote timely and effective actions with efficiency on behalf of the Government. (
) Internal Revenue Manual (IRM)

, Bankruptcy and Other Insolvencies, contains the Service’s position, procedures, information, instructions, and references concerning bankruptcy cases, stockbroker insolvencies, erships, assignments for the beneﬁt of creditors, corporate dissolutions and bulk sales. (
) The Insolvency program operates within the guidelines of the US Code (
USC) and the Federal Rules of Bankruptcy Procedure. (
) IRM
, Authority, and IRM
, Responsibilities, contain Insol- vency caseworkers’ authority and responsibilities in the Insolvency program. (
) IRM
, Overview of Bankruptcy, provides a list of titles and with an explanation of their roles and authority within the Insolvency (
) The Director, Specialty Collection - Insolvency (SCI) is responsible for the program oversight. (
) IRM
, Case Management Tools, IRM
, Insolvency Process, and IRM

, Insolvency Case Monitoring, contain a list of Management required reports for caseworkers and managers to utilize for inventory ment and review of case inventories. These also include the frequency and purpose of each report. (
) Operational and program reviews are conducted on a yearly basis. See
, Operational Review, and IRM
, Program Reviews, more information. (
) Managers are required to follow program management procedures and controls addressed in IRM
, Reviews (Overview), IRM
, Controls Controls, and IRM
, Quality. (
) Caseworkers and managers utilize the Automated Insolvency System (AIS) case management, assignment, and documentation of all insolvency and (

IRM 5.9.1, Overview of Bankruptcy, provides a list of titles and responsibilities with an explanation of their roles and authority within the Insolvency program.
Caseworkers and managers utilize the Automated Insolvency System (AIS) for case management, assignment, and documentation of all insolvency and non-
5.9 Bankruptcy and Other Insolvencies
bankruptcy insolvency cases. Access and permissions to AIS are restricted. See IRM 5.9.3.2, Automated Insolvency System (AIS).
Some acronyms used speciﬁcally in this IRM section are listed below:

) The Taxpayer Bill of Rights (TBOR) lists rights that already existed in code, putting them in simple language and grouping them into
rights. Employees are responsible for being familiar with and acting in dance with taxpayer rights. See IRC
), Execution of Duties in

The Taxpayer Bill of Rights (TBOR) lists rights that already existed in the tax code, putting them in simple language and grouping them into 10 fundamental rights. Employees are responsible for being familiar with and acting in accor- dance with taxpayer rights. See IRC 7803(a)(3), Execution of Duties in Accord
with Taxpayer Rights. For more additional information about the TBOR, see https://www.irs.gov/taxpayer-bill-of-rights.
(1) National Addresses. The Internal Revenue Service has established two national addresses for the receipt of Insolvency mail.
Payments and remittances are to(09 be sent to Insolvency Remittance-Post Office Box 7317, Philadelphia, PA 19101-7317

Administrative mail such as court documents, forms, general correspondence, and other bankruptcy-related communications should be sent to - Centralized Insolvency Operation Post Office Box 7346, Philadelphia, PA 19101-7346.

Local Addresses. From a standpoint of practicality, some mail may to be mailed to local Field Insolvency (FI) addresses. However, mail better handled at the Centralized Insolvency Operation (CIO) and received at a office should be faxed (if “expedite”) or sent by overnight courier to the CIO street address:
Market St., Mail Stop
-Q
, Philadelphia, PA
(See , IRM

), Expedite Mail for the CIO.) Local Mail Receipt. Mail received by Field Insolvency offices must be date stamped upon receipt. When multiple documents are received in one envelope, the front page of each document must be stamped individually. signment of mail opening, stamping, sorting, and distribution is determined local Insolvency management. Mail Meant for CIO. Mail that may be received in the Field, but normally worked by Centralized Insolvency includes the following: • Notices of bankruptcy ﬁlings (
notices) • Correspondence on cases assigned to CIO • Chapter
or

trustee payments • Documents from courts, Counsel, AUSA, and trustees for cases assigned to CIO The nature of these receipts must be reviewed to determine if expedited handling is required. Expedite Mail for the CIO. Mail to be considered as “expedite” includes: • First notices of bankruptcy ﬁlings for all chapters • Form

, Request for Taxpayer Advocate Service Assistance (And plication for Taxpayer Assistance Order), for cases assigned to the • Violations of the automatic stay for cases assigned to the CIO • Any notice/order/objection naming the Service and giving a deadline respond for cases assigned to the CIO

Market St., Mail Stop

(See , IRM

Local Addresses. From a standpoint of practicality, some mail may continue to be mailed to local Field Insolvency (FI) addresses. However, mail better handled at the Centralized Insolvency Operation (CIO) and received at a Field office should be faxed (if “expedite”) or sent by overnight courier to the CIO street address: 2970 Market St., Mail Stop 5-Q30-133, Philadelphia, PA 19104- 5016. (See , IRM 5.9.11.3(3), Expedite Mail for the CIO.)

• Notices of bankruptcy ﬁlings (
notices) • Correspondence on cases assigned to CIO • Chapter
or
trustee payments • Documents from courts, Counsel, AUSA, and trustees for cases assigned to CIO
The nature of these receipts must be reviewed to determine if expedited handling is required.
Expedite Mail for the CIO. Mail to be considered as “expedite”
• First notices of bankruptcy ﬁlings for all chapters • Form

, Request for Taxpayer Advocate Service Assistance (And Ap- plication for Taxpayer Assistance Order), for cases assigned to the CIO • Violations of the automatic stay for cases assigned to the CIO • Any notice/order/objection naming the Service and giving a deadline to respond for cases assigned to the CIO • Mail requiring action within
calendar days for cases assigned to the

Form 911, Request for Taxpayer Advocate Service Assistance (And Ap- plication for Taxpayer Assistance Order), for cases assigned to the CIO Violations of the automatic stay for cases assigned to the CIO Any notice/order/objection naming the Service and giving a deadline to respond for cases assigned to the CIO Mail requiring action within 10 calendar days for cases assigned to the
Expedite mail that will eventually be handled by FI even though the case is currently residing at the CIO, such as adversary proceedings or Chapter
amendments to plans, should be retained and worked by FI. FI should reassign the case to FI’s inventory until the issue is resolved, at which time the case can be transferred back to the CIO.
Bankruptcy and Other (

) Specialty Mail Received by the Field. A Field Insolvency office may mail for a special proceeding being worked by another Field office. • Securities Investor Protection Act (SIPA) cases are worked by St. Paul Insolvency for Area West, and by Manhattan Insolvency for Area East. • All Foreign Bank and Financial Account Reports (FBAR) cases are worked by Los Angeles Insolvency. • All Chapter

, Cross-Border Insolvency cases are worked by the FI office in Philadelphia. • All FDIC Receivership cases are worked by the FI office in Dallas. Mail concerning these cases received in other FI offices must be forwarded the appropriate Insolvency office following the expedite procedures in paragraph (
) below. (

) Expedite Mail Procedures for the Field. When a piece of mail is identiﬁed “expedite”, the assigned FI employee must transmit a copy by fax to a desig- nated CIO liaison on the day of receipt. After the fax has been sent, the FI employee must telephone the liaison to advise the CIO that a fax has been transmitted which requires immediate attention. (

) Solicited Mail. Courts are expected to send all notices to the national post office box because it is listed as the Service’s address of record for all court generated documents. But local Insolvency caseworkers should ask debtors, trustees, and debtors-in-possession involved with Chapter
, and
cases to mail correspondence directly to the local office address. If mail from those sources, other than payments, is received at the CIO, it will be forwarded to the appropriate FI office. (

) Mail Forwarded from the CIO. When CIO caseworkers forward mail to FI, and FI determines no action is needed on the correspondence, the receiving caseworker must annotate in the AIS history the correspondence has been received and no actions were taken. Then, the unnecessary correspondence should be placed in classiﬁed waste. The mail should not be returned to the CIO unless the CIO has a demonstrable need to work that speciﬁc piece of correspondence. If that is the case, the FI caseworker must explain in the history why that correspondence requires CIO action. Refer to IRM Document Disposition, for guidance on handling classiﬁed waste documents. (

) Original Returns. If appropriate, FI should request debtors to mail original petition tax returns directly to the local Insolvency office address. In cases where multiple returns are received in a single envelope, a received date be stamped on the front page of each return. (See IRM
), trative Mail, Tax Returns, for additional information on date stamping.) The margin of the ﬁrst sheet of the original returns should be annotated with “TC
cc
”. Within one business day of receipt, the return, along with any attached payment, must be sent overnight to the delegated Campus for pro- cessing. Form
must accompany the returns and remittances annotating the: • Volume and return type(s) (e.g.,
) • TIN(s) • Dollar amount(s) of the check(s) Note: If an Insolvency caseworker cannot review a return before it is sent for pro- cessing, photocopies should be made for later review.
5.9 Bankruptcy and Other Insolvencies
Specialty Mail Received by the Field. A Field Insolvency office may receive mail for a special proceeding being worked by another Field office.

Securities Investor Protection Act (SIPA) cases are worked by St. Paul Insolvency for Area West, and by Manhattan Insolvency for Area East. All Foreign Bank and Financial Account Reports (FBAR) cases are worked by Los Angeles Insolvency. All Chapter
, Cross-Border Insolvency cases are worked by the FI office in Philadelphia. All FDIC Receivership cases are worked by the FI office in Dallas.
Note: If an Insolvency caseworker cannot review a return before it is sent for cessing, photocopies should be made for later review.

) Trustee Payments. Although the Office of the US Trustee has advised trustees of the national address for mailing Chapter
and Chapter
payments, some Chapter
or Chapter
trustee payments may be sent to local offices in error. After being date stamped, these misdirected checks trustees should be mailed overnight to the CIO Payment Posting Unit using Form
, Document Transmittal. For trustee checks, Form
must list check(s) received from the trustee(s) by check number and the trustee’s last name. The checks must be sent to Centralized Insolvency Operation,
Market St., Mail Stop
-Q
, Philadelphia, PA
Note: Chapter
and
checks should be posted by the FI office assigned to cases and forwarded to the Remittance Processing Units in the Campuses. (See IRM
, Payments in Bankruptcy.) (

) Mail Receipts. Insolvency mail received at the CIO consists of letters, court documents, correspondence, plans, forms, payments and other communica- tions. CIO caseworkers sort and distribute the administrative receipts to the appropriate CIO units or Field Insolvency (FI) groups. All mail concerning Chapters
, or
, with the exception of
notices, is sent to the propriate FI offices regardless of the nature of the mail. (

) Live Checks. “Live” checks (those that are negotiable) are not to leave the Campus Support function of the mail room. If a live check (not a photocopy) received outside of the Campus Support function, it must be returned to the mail room immediately. Bankruptcy payments remitted by the bankruptcy estate and received by Centralized Insolvency will be processed at the Campus site regardless of chapter type. Procedures for advising FI ers of Chapter
, Chapter
, and Chapter
payments received and at the CIO can be found in IRM
, Payments in Bankruptcy. (

) Mail Receipt. The CIO support units receive mail based on a daily schedule set by the Campus Support function. Mail received for Insolvency is by Campus Support. Insolvency mail caseworkers must date stamp the front page of each document received in the Centralized site. (

) Tax Returns. Original tax returns are sometimes delivered through mail. The front page of each tax return received by FI or CIO must be stamped with the IRS received date using an official IRS date stamp. If an official IRS date stamp is not available, the caseworker must write the date received (Received MM/DD/YYYY), along with caseworker signature and in the upper left hand margin of the ﬁrst page of the tax return. A valid hand written received date stamp consists of the following: • The word “Received” • Month, day and year (in MM/DD/YYYY format) • Caseworker signature • Title “Technician” or “Bankruptcy Specialist” Original returns involving all bankruptcy chapters (except Chapter
No must be photocopied by the mail unit. CIO caseworkers must input TC
on the appropriate master ﬁle tax (MFT) and tax period using FRM
to indicate an original return has been received. After the photocopies are and the TC
s are input, the returns must be reviewed by the CIO case-

payments, some Chapter
or Chapter
trustee payments may be sent to local offices in error. After being date stamped, these misdirected checks from trustees should be mailed overnight to the CIO Payment Posting Unit using Form

Chapter 11 and 12 checks should be posted by the FI office assigned to the cases and forwarded to the Remittance Processing Units in the appropriate Campuses. (See IRM 5.9.15, Payments in Bankruptcy.)

Insolvency mail caseworkers must date stamp the page of each document received in the Centralized site. Tax Returns. Original tax returns are sometimes delivered through mail. The front page of each tax return received by FI or CIO must be stamped with the IRS received date using an official IRS date stamp. page of each document received in the Centralized site. Tax Returns. Original tax returns are sometimes delivered through Insolvency mail. The front page of each tax return received by FI or CIO must be stamped with the IRS received date using an official IRS date stamp. If an official IRS date stamp is not available, the caseworker must write the date received (Received MM/DD/YYYY), along with caseworker signature and title, in the upper left hand margin of the ﬁrst page of the tax return. A valid hand written received date stamp consists of the following:
The word “Received” Month, day and year (in MM/DD/YYYY format) Caseworker signature Title “Technician” or “Bankruptcy Specialist”

Original returns involving all bankruptcy chapters (except Chapter 7 No Asset) must be photocopied by the mail unit. CIO caseworkers must input TC 599 cc 067 on the appropriate master ﬁle tax (MFT) and tax period using FRM49 to indicate an original return has been received. After the photocopies are made and the TC 599s are input, the returns must be reviewed by the CIO case- workers to identify those that are considered “statute imminent returns” by

referring to the Statute Alert issued for Campus processing. CIO will establish local procedures for processing statute imminent returns by taxpayers in bankruptcy. (IRM

When moving mail out of the Mail Support Team groups or to other CIO units, caseworkers must prepare Form

, Transmittal, to accompany the referenced mail item(s). Types of Mail. Administrative mail is classiﬁed into the following a. Time Sensitive Mail. Mail setting a deadline date for an IRS within ﬁfteen calendar days is considered time sensitive and must given expedited handling. b. Routine Insolvency Mail. Routine mail gives notice of a case action, does not require an immediate response or may not require any response from the Service. It may be routine mail requiring further cessing, or routine mail requiring no further processing. c. Direct to Classiﬁed Waste. This is bankruptcy mail that has no the Service’s handling of a case. will establish local procedures for processing statute imminent returns by taxpayers in bankruptcy. (IRM

, After Hours & Imminent Assess- ments, provide information for addressing statute imminent returns.) Returns not meeting the statute imminent return criteria must be forwarded overnight the appropriate Campus for processing. The photocopies will be sent by fax overnight mail to the FI caseworker currently assigned the case. Transmittal Required. When moving mail out of the Mail Support Team to groups or to other CIO units, caseworkers must prepare Form

, Transmittal, to accompany the referenced mail item(s). Types of Mail. Administrative mail is classiﬁed into the following categories: a. Time Sensitive Mail. Mail setting a deadline date for an IRS response within ﬁfteen calendar days is considered time sensitive and must be given expedited handling. b. Routine Insolvency Mail. Routine mail gives notice of a case action, but does not require an immediate response or may not require any response from the Service. It may be routine mail requiring further pro- cessing, or routine mail requiring no further processing. c. Direct to Classiﬁed Waste. This is bankruptcy mail that has no bearing the Service’s handling of a case. (Exhibit

, Mail Direct to Classi- ﬁed Waste) d. Non-Insolvency Mail. Mis-routed mail is correspondence that does not belong to Insolvency. Identifying Time Sensitive Mail. For Insolvency purposes, the deﬁnition of “time sensitive” mail is documents and letters that require some kind of IRS action within ﬁfteen calendar days. Examples of mail that can be time include the following: • Objection to proof of claim • Notice of levy • Notice of lien • Notice of hearing to waive

meeting of creditors • Motion to sell property free and clear of liens • Notice of emergency hearing (involving IRS) • Adversary proceeding (involving IRS) • Notice of summons and complaint (involving IRS) • Automatic stay violations • Any notice/order/objection naming IRS and giving a deadline to • Motion for a cash collateral agreement • Notice of §

hearing (and case not loaded onto AIS) • Urgent correspondence from attorneys, Area Counsel, or other inter- ested parties • FBAR correspondence (to be forwarded to Los Angeles Insolvency) • Prompt Determination Requests see IRM
• Prompt Refund Requests see IRM
• Motion to determine dischargeability under Bankruptcy Code

Returns not meeting the statute imminent return criteria must be forwarded overnight to the appropriate Campus for processing. The photocopies will be sent by fax or overnight mail to the FI caseworker currently assigned the case.

) Specialty Mail for Field Insolvency. In addition to bankruptcies, the Field In- solvency operation handles receiverships, assignments for the beneﬁt of creditors, FBAR bankruptcies, SIPA proceedings, and review of the Consoli- dated Appropriations Act (CAA) effective December

When the CIO receives correspondence on any of these issues, that mail must be processed using time sensitive procedures. a. Receiverships and Assignments. FDIC mail regarding receiverships and assignments for the beneﬁt of creditors must be forwarded to the office Dallas and all non-FDIC mail regarding receiverships and assignments for the beneﬁt of creditors must be forwarded to the local FI office handling that court’s jurisdiction. b. SIPA Procedures. All mail concerning SIPA proceedings for jurisdictions in Insolvency Area East must be forwarded to the Manhattan Insolvency office. All mail concerning SIPA proceedings for jurisdictions in Area West must be forwarded to the St. Paul Insolvency office. c. FBAR Correspondence. All FBAR mail must be forwarded to the Los Angeles office for processing. d. Consolidated Appropriations Act (CAA). All mail regarding motions to determine dischargeability under Bankruptcy Code
USC
(i) must be forwarded to the local FI office to review the impact and potential effect of BC
USC
(i) on Chapter
discharges that took into effect on December
See IRM
)(g), Chapter
and Consolidated Appropriations Act (CAA). Note: Specialty mail may be forwarded by scanning and emailing the documents the appropriate office. (

) Processing Time Sensitive Mail. If the mail is time sensitive, the caseworker must query the case on the Automated Insolvency System (AIS) or the Inte- grated Data Retrieval System (IDRS) to determine where and to whom the case is assigned. (See Exhibit
, Accessing a Case on AIS and Document
, AIS User Guide.) (

) AIS Research. When the case appears on the AIS screen, the name and docket number must match the debtor name and the docket number on the notice. The state in which the bankruptcy was ﬁled can help identify the case. The court jurisdiction code within a state (e.g., ILN for Illinois North) also be helpful. (

) Advising Field Insolvency. Within two workdays of receipt, the CIO case- worker must advise FI of the notice. Methods of advice may include: • Transmission of a secure e-mail to a designated FI group e-mail box with a “read receipt” request; • Sending a copy of the notice via overnight delivery to the FI assigned the case; or • Faxing a copy to the FI caseworker or group secretary, preceded by a phone call to advise the office of the fax. Note: Managerial approval is required for overnight shipping.

Specialty Mail for Field Insolvency. In addition to bankruptcies, the Field In- solvency operation handles receiverships, assignments for the beneﬁt of creditors, FBAR bankruptcies, SIPA proceedings, and review of the Consoli- dated Appropriations Act (CAA) effective December
When the CIO receives correspondence on any of these issues, that mail must be processed using time sensitive procedures.

Specialty Mail for Field Insolvency. In addition to bankruptcies, the Field In- solvency operation handles receiverships, assignments for the beneﬁt of creditors, FBAR bankruptcies, SIPA proceedings, and review of the Consoli- dated Appropriations Act (CAA) effective December 27, 2020. When the CIO receives correspondence on any of these issues, that mail must be processed using time sensitive procedures.

Receiverships and Assignments. FDIC mail regarding receiverships and assignments for the beneﬁt of creditors must be forwarded to the office Dallas and all non-FDIC mail regarding receiverships and assignments for the beneﬁt of creditors must be forwarded to the local FI office handling that court’s jurisdiction. SIPA Procedures. All mail concerning SIPA proceedings for jurisdictions in Insolvency Area East must be forwarded to the Manhattan Insolvency office. All mail concerning SIPA proceedings for jurisdictions in Area West must be forwarded to the St. Paul Insolvency office. FBAR Correspondence. All FBAR mail must be forwarded to the Los Angeles office for processing. Consolidated Appropriations Act (CAA). All mail regarding motions to determine dischargeability under Bankruptcy Code
USC
(i) be forwarded to the local FI office to review the impact and potential effect of BC
USC
(i) on Chapter
discharges that took into effect on December

Consolidated Appropriations Act (CAA).
Specialty mail may be forwarded by scanning and emailing the documents to

Processing Time Sensitive Mail. If the mail is time sensitive, the must query the case on the Automated Insolvency System (AIS) or the Inte- grated Data Retrieval System (IDRS) to determine where and to whom the case is assigned. (See Exhibit
, Accessing a Case on AIS and Document

, AIS User Guide.) AIS Research. When the case appears on the AIS screen, the name and docket number must match the debtor name and the docket number on the notice. The state in which the bankruptcy was ﬁled can help identify the case. The court jurisdiction code within a state (e.g., ILN for Illinois North) also be helpful. Advising Field Insolvency. Within two workdays of receipt, the CIO case- worker must advise FI of the notice. Methods of advice may include: • Transmission of a secure e-mail to a designated FI group e-mail box with a “read receipt” request; • Sending a copy of the notice via overnight delivery to the FI assigned the case; or • Faxing a copy to the FI caseworker or group secretary, preceded by a phone call to advise the office of the fax.
Transmission of a secure e
mail to a designated FI group e

mail box with a “read receipt” request; Sending a copy of the notice via overnight delivery to the FI caseworker assigned the case; or Faxing a copy to the FI caseworker or group secretary, preceded by a phone call to advise the office of the fax.
Note: Managerial approval is required for overnight shipping.

The preferred method for time sensitive communication is e-mail. A copy of the e-mail will be retained for 60 days. If an Out-of-Office (OOO) response is received, the original message will be forwarded to the individual designated in the OOO message. No action will be taken to conﬁrm the receipt of informa-
Bankruptcy and Other tion submitted via e-mail. It will be assumed the employee is receiving messages unless an OOO message is received. (
) Documentation. The mail caseworker must document the AIS case history brieﬂy with the nature of the time sensitive mail and the actions taken. (
) Assigned to Campus. If the case is assigned to Centralized Insolvency the caseworker must identify, sort, and forward time sensitive mail to Field solvency.. (

) Routine Mail. Routine mail does not require an immediate IRS response, may not require an IRS response at all. Routine mail can be a motion, Mail or order advising the Service of an action. This type of mail may include: • Order of dismissal • Order of discharge • Order of conversion • Notice of possible dividend • Other routine notice • Photocopy of an Insolvency check • Acknowledgement of receipt of a proof of claim (

) Routine Mail and AIS Action. In processing routine mail, the caseworker must determine if AIS processing is required by the Mail Support Team, as the input of dismissal or conversion dates. In cases where AIS data be input, the caseworker must query the case referenced in the correspon- dence on AIS. (See Exhibit
, Accessing a Case on AIS and/or Document

, AIS User Guide.) After the caseworker has veriﬁed that name, taxpayer identiﬁcation number (TIN), and docket number on the match the name on the AIS screen, (s)he must document the type of notice received and what action, if any, is being taken. (

) Disposition. When mail is a routine notice or order (not time sensitive) requiring further processing and the CIO caseworker accesses the case AIS, if the case is assigned to FI, the CIO caseworker must annotate the standard employee identiﬁcation (SEID) designation in the upper right corner of the document before forwarding it to FI. The caseworker must prepare Form
, Document Transmittal, to accompany mail leaving Support Team. AIS documentation of receipt of this mail by CIO not required. (

) Time Frame. The CIO must forward routine mail to FI offices, if necessary, at least twice weekly, using the most cost effective method of day delivery. The choice is up to the discretion of CIO management. (

) No Further Processing Required. Routine notices received from the ruptcy court requiring no further processing may include the following: • Motion or application to employ another attorney/accountant • Duplicate notices of any kind • Copy of a petition and the case is already loaded on AIS Note: Chapter type and petition date should be veriﬁed with AIS before discarding potentially duplicate petitions. • Order approving reaffirmation agreement • Order granting a motion to amend schedules • Notice pursuant to Rule
• Motion to abandon property (unless Notice of Federal Tax Lien • Payment of priority claim wages (

) Review and Documentation. If the mail is a routine notice or order no further processing, the caseworker should query the case on AIS and document the case regarding the type of notice received unless the notice duplication of an earlier notice. The documentation should be brief. After mentation, the mail can be discarded in classiﬁed waste. Refer to IRM
, Document Disposition, for guidance on handling classiﬁed documents.
No Further Processing Required. Routine notices received from the ruptcy court requiring no further processing may include the following:

, or
cases, except those items identiﬁed on the classiﬁed waste list, must be forwarded to the appropriate FI office via Form

5.9 Bankruptcy and Other Insolvencies
STEP ACTION
Access the case on AIS. (See Exhibit
Accessing a Case on AIS and/or Document
, AIS User Guide.)
Review the AIS Taxpayer Screen to determine if a dismissal date is present.

If a dismissal date has been entered, or if the case has otherwise been closed as no liability or full paid, no action is necessary. The dismissal order should be placed in clas- siﬁed waste unless otherwise directed by the manager.

If no date is present, input the: • Dismissal date, and • “Closed Noticed” ﬁeld, if required. Update the AIS history to reﬂect receipt of the document and any other appropriate information; e.g. dismissed for failure to meet the means test. These inputs cause the dismissed case to appear on the court closure report, so the technical units or FI caseworkers can take the ﬁnal closing actions. IRM
), Caseworker Actions, lists issues that may need to be resolved before closing a case, some of which pertain to dismissals.
5.9.11.4.6 (11-08-2022) Discharge Orders
Actions on Paper Discharges. If the mail being sorted is an order for discharge, the Insolvency caseworker must take the following steps.
Access the case on AIS (see Exhibit
, Accessing a Case on AIS and/or Document
, AIS User Guide).

To ensure a discharge is processed correctly, it is extremely important to verify the proper chapter type is listed on AIS. If the chapter type does not match; take action to convert the case on AIS. See IRM
, Conversion or Dividend.
Distribution. Duplicate correspondence or correspondence cited on the classi

ﬁed waste list requires no AIS history documentation. Receipt of other correspondence must be documented on AIS if it is routine and will be disposed of in classiﬁed waste or is correspondence that requires special handling such as time sensitive mail or original tax returns. Caseworkers do not need to annotate the AIS history concerning routine correspondence being forwarded to FI or to other areas of the CIO.
Reminder: All correspondence forwarded outside of the Mail Support Team working mail must be listed on Form 3210, Document Transmittal.
Managerial Review and Oversight All documents deemed “Classiﬁed Waste” by a caseworker should be available for managerial review and oversight prior to being placed in the classiﬁed waste bin. IRM

), Quality, states, “Managers are responsible for the quality of all work assigned to their group and for all work which leaves their group regardless of the methods used. Managers must devise a system of quality control which works for them.” Records Retention. Refer to IRM

, Responsibilities of All IRS Employees and Contractors, for disposition authorization before discarding cor- respondence as classiﬁed waste. Certain mail documents may be placed in the classiﬁed waste bin when they are no longer needed for administrative, legal,

Records Retention. Refer to IRM 1.15.1.3.6, Responsibilities of All IRS Employees and Contractors, for disposition authorization before discarding cor- respondence as classiﬁed waste. Certain mail documents may be placed in classiﬁed waste bin when they are no longer needed for administrative, legal, audit or other operational purposes. Employees must follow official guidance

provided for records retention. Records cannot be destroyed without approval from the National Archives Records Administration (NARA).
Order of Conversion or Notice of Possible Dividend. Chapter

Asset case may also be identiﬁed as “Notice of Assets” or “Notice to File Proof of Claim”. When an Order for Conversion or Notice of Possible Dividend is received, the Insolvency caseworker must take the following steps.

12, or Chapter 13 cases may be converted to Chapter 7 Asset or No Asset cases, and Chapter 7 Asset cases may be converted to Chapter 7 No Asset cases. Occasionally, a Chapter 7 case is converted to a Chapter 11 proceed- ing. Most bankruptcy courts open Chapter 7 cases as no asset cases. A of Possible Dividend converts a Chapter 7 No Asset case to a Chapter 7 Asset case. Conversions to a Chapter 7 Asset case may also be identiﬁed as “Notice of Assets” or “Notice to File Proof of Claim”. When an Order for Conversion or Notice of Possible Dividend is received, the Insolvency caseworker must take the following steps.
STEP ACTION
Access the case on AIS (See Exhibit
, Accessing a Case on AIS and/or Document
, AIS User Guide).
Review the AIS Taxpayer Screen to determine if the con- version date is present.
If the correct conversion date is present, place the notice in classiﬁed waste.
If no date is present, input the “Converted by Court” ﬁeld, the new
meeting date, if any, the new bar date, if any, and the chapter to which the case is converted. If the notice does not provide a bar date, input the bar date as
days from the
meeting date.

If a paper Notice of Conversion is received, review the trustee information to determine if the trustee has been changed. If so, input the new trustee information on AIS. If the previous trustee had requested a refund turnover, the “TTEE RFND” on the “Classiﬁcation” Screen and annotate actions taken in the AIS history. Check for the appropriate
closing code. If different, change the closing code on IDRS. Remove the follow up date from the Letter Screen. (See IRM Exhibit
, Conversions and Turnover Requests, for additional information.)
If the case is assigned to a FI employee, notify the employee via secured e-mail, fax, or telephone of the con- version.
If necessary, transfer the case to the proper FI or CIO caseworker. (See IRM Exhibit
, Transfer Steps for Cases with No Open Conﬁrmed Plan Monitoring (CPM) or No Open Other Investigation Screen, and IRM Exhibit
, Transfer Steps for Cases with an Open Conﬁrmed Plan Monitoring (CPM) Plan Screen.)
If the case is assigned to the CIO, walk the notice to the CIO team lead or deliver by any other approved method of distribution.

cases, pre-petition refunds are considered part of the estate. In Chapter

) When a trustee decides that he/she no longer has an interest in the taxpayer’s refund, the trustee will notice IRS. The title of the notice may vary from court court. Such notices may be titled “Vacate Turnover”, “Reverse Request for Refund”, “Release the Trustee’s Directive for Refund”, or “Order Abandoning Trustee’s Interest in Refund”. Follow the instructions in Exhibit
, Pro- cessing Withdrawals or Rescissions of Trustee Requests, when this type of notice is received. (

) Misrouted Mail. Mail is sometimes misrouted to the Insolvency mail drop. The caseworker should query AIS and, if necessary, IDRS, to determine the intended destination of the mail. If the mail is non-Insolvency, the caseworker should make a reasonable attempt to determine the correct mail address and forward it accordingly. If the proper recipient cannot be determined, the case- worker should return it to Campus Support.

5.9 Bankruptcy and Other Insolvencies

) Returned Mail. Mail sent by the Service to the last address of record or the address provided in the bankruptcy records may be returned to the sender (UD) Mail (CIO or FI) as undeliverable (UD). The United States Postal Service (USPS) has abbreviations to explain why UD mail is being returned, such as FOE (for- warding order expired) or UAA (undeliverable as addressed). Processing of mail depends on the return address of the sender and the nature of the corre- spondence. (

) That’s National Change of Address (NCOA) Database. An address from the National Change of Address (NCOA) database becomes the taxpay- er’s last known address until the taxpayer subsequently provides clear and concise notiﬁcation of a change of address or the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) properly processes a taxpayer’s federal income tax return with a address. Upon receipt of any undeliverable mail piece with an affixed United States Postal Service (USPS) yellow label, an IRS office should examine, research, and update the address as follows: a. If the taxpayer’s address of record differs from the “yellow label” and the name printed on the “yellow label” is an exact match to the correspon- dence, then update the taxpayer’s address of record to the “yellow label” address. Reissue the correspondence to the taxpayer’s updated b. If the taxpayer’s ﬁrst name is not an exact match with that on the “yellow label,” but the last name is an exact match, then conﬁrm whether IRS records show any other taxpayers with similar ﬁrst names and the exact same last name at the same address as the address shown on the “yellow label.” If not, then update the taxpayer address. Otherwise, do update the taxpayer address. c. In all other cases do not update the taxpayer address unless and until a correct address is obtained using further efforts described in the paragraph. d. Further efforts to obtain a current address may include, but are not limited to - :i) Using the Locator Services System Update - Address Research (LSS-ADR) to issue Letter
, Undeliverable Mail System Update, known as “R U There?” to obtain the taxpayer’s current mailing address, if applicable, or - ii) Preparing/issuing IDRS Letter
C, liverable Mail - New Address Veriﬁcation, to request veriﬁcation and provide the appropriate change of address form. Include a copy of the appropriate Form
, Change of Address. Rev. Proc.
and Treas. Reg.
govern the update of a tax- payer’s address in IRS records. See also IRM
, Mail and Transportation Management - Mail Operations.

) Returned Mail. Mail sent by the Service to the last address of record or the address provided in the bankruptcy records may be returned to the sender (CIO or FI) as undeliverable (UD). The United States Postal Service (USPS) has abbreviations to explain why UD mail is being returned, such as FOE (for- warding order expired) or UAA (undeliverable as addressed). Processing of mail depends on the return address of the sender and the nature of the corre- spondence. (

) That’s National Change of Address (NCOA) Database. An address obtained from the National Change of Address (NCOA) database becomes the taxpay- er’s last known address until the taxpayer subsequently provides clear and concise notiﬁcation of a change of address or the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) properly processes a taxpayer’s federal income tax return with a different address. Upon receipt of any undeliverable mail piece with an affixed United States Postal Service (USPS) yellow label, an IRS office should examine, research, and update the address as follows:

a. If the taxpayer’s address of record differs from the “yellow label” and the name printed on the “yellow label” is an exact match to the correspon- dence, then update the taxpayer’s address of record to the “yellow label” address. Reissue the correspondence to the taxpayer’s updated b. If the taxpayer’s ﬁrst name is not an exact match with that on the label,” but the last name is an exact match, then conﬁrm whether IRS records show any other taxpayers with similar ﬁrst names and the exact same last name at the same address as the address shown on the “yellow label.” If not, then update the taxpayer address. Otherwise, do update the taxpayer address. c. In all other cases do not update the taxpayer address unless and until a correct address is obtained using further efforts described in the paragraph. d. Further efforts to obtain a current address may include, but are not limited to - :i) Using the Locator Services System Update - Address Research (LSS-ADR) to issue Letter
, Undeliverable Mail System Update, known as “R U There?” to obtain the taxpayer’s current mailing address, if applicable, or - ii) Preparing/issuing IDRS Letter
C, liverable Mail - New Address Veriﬁcation, to request veriﬁcation and provide the appropriate change of address form. Include a copy of the appropriate Form
, Change of Address.
Rev. Proc.
and Treas. Reg.
govern the update of a tax- payer’s address in IRS records. See also IRM

, Mail and Transportation Management - Mail Operations. Field Insolvency UD Mail. Field Insolvency necessarily sends some mail to debtors, attorneys, trustees, and third parties giving the local Insolvency location as the return address. When this mail is returned to the local office as UD, depending on the urgency of the mail and local practice, the caseworker receiving the UD mail is responsible for obtaining a correct mailing address for the mail recipient. The AIS history must be updated with the nature of the mail, who was to have received the mail, and if appropriate, what steps were taken to secure a valid address, and if the correspondence was resent to a newly found address. If a determination is made not to pursue a new address, the correspondence should be disposed of in classiﬁed waste. Refer to IRM
, Document Disposition, for guidance on handling classiﬁed waste documents.
Mail Processing 5.9.11

CIO UD Mail. The bulk of correspondence going to debtors has the national post office box for the CIO as the return address. Consequently, most UD mail will be received by the CIO. The CIO’s processing of UD mail depends on the correspondence being returned. For guidance on handling classiﬁed waste documents, refer to IRM 5.9.11.4.7, Document Disposition.

post office box for the CIO as the return address. Consequently, most UD will be received by the CIO. The CIO’s processing of UD mail depends on the correspondence being returned. For guidance on handling classiﬁed waste documents, refer to IRM
, Document Disposition. a. Letter
When Letter

(notices advising debtors of missing tax returns) are received by the CIO as undeliverable, the CIO caseworker should annotate in the AIS history that the letter has been returned as UD and give enough of the bad address so anyone attempting to mail subsequent correspondence to the debtor will not use the bad address. After the AIS history has been updated, the UD mail should be of in classiﬁed waste. b. Letter
-C. When Letter

-C, Installment Agreement; Terms Explained, to reinstate an accepted Installment Agreement is returned undeliverable (UD) mail, the CIO caseworker should update the AIS history that the letter has been returned as UD and give enough of the bad address so anyone attempting to mail subsequent correspondence the debtor will not use the bad address. After the AIS history has been updated, the UD mail should be disposed of in classiﬁed waste. c. Letter
-C. When Letter

-C, Intent to Terminate Your Installment Agreement (Spouse), is returned as undeliverable, CIO caseworker should update the AIS history that the letter has been returned as UD and give enough of the bad address so anyone attempting to mail quent correspondence to the non-debtor spouse (NDS) will not use the bad address. After the AIS history has been updated, the UD mail be disposed of in classiﬁed waste. d. Letter
(CG). When Letter

(CG), Post Petition Liability (notices advising debtors of post-petition debt and asking for payment) is to the CIO as undeliverable, the CIO caseworker should update the AIS history stating the letter has been returned as UD and give enough of bad address so subsequent correspondence to the debtor will not be sent to the bad address. After the AIS history has been updated, the mail should be disposed of in classiﬁed waste. Then the case should be reassigned to FI for processing in the manner appropriate for that local office. e. Letter
(CG). When Letter
(CG), Stat

Letter, advising to stop making installment agreement payments are returned as UD the CIO caseworker must update the AIS history stating the letter has been returned as UD and give enough of the bad address so correspondence will not be sent to the bad address. The case should transferred to FI. The FI caseworker must attempt to locate a current address for the debtor, usually by contacting the debtor’s attorney. After the AIS history has been updated, the UD mail should be disposed of in classiﬁed waste. Reminder: FI caseworkers are responsible for resolving stay violations cases assigned to them.

CIO employees may discard the following categories of mail for Chapter 9, 11, and 12 cases without annotating their receipt on AIS:
• Duplicate
notices where the
date is already present on AIS • Original

notices after the notice has been added to AIS • Original plans • Schedules • Conﬁrmation orders • All documents on closed cases with the exception of an order to vacate the dismissal or or an amended/modiﬁed disclosure statement or an amended/modiﬁed plan
